text:
IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM  
R v. Mr H  
Case No. B2025/34560  
Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. M. Davenport  
Filed: 15 September 2025

Mr H stands before this court for sentence on two counts: the first, engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006; the second, possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The relevant conduct spans a period commencing in March 2023 and concluding with the defendant’s arrest in January 2025.

From the outset, it is appropriate to acknowledge the diligent work undertaken by Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands (CTPWM) in this matter. Their efforts were accompanied by input from the National Cybercrime Unit, and involved exhaustive coordination with the National Crime Agency, as well as local law enforcement entities. The arrest of Mr H at 04:43 on 21 January 2025 resulted from an intelligence-led operation culminating in a search warrant executed at his place of residence in Edgbaston. This warrant had been authorised under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_1}

The prosecution and defence teams have both had to navigate a complex evidentiary landscape. The volume of electronically stored information comprised over 2.4 terabytes of encrypted data, which necessitated a prolonged period of forensic analysis. This process was hampered intermittently by compatibility issues with decryption software routinely used by the National Technical Assistance Centre (NTAC). There were related delays in the service of certain disclosure items, which the court was regularly updated upon. Notably, the Legal Aid Agency’s administrative delays in granting authorisation for expert forensic services added an element of procedural contortion in the early stages of these proceedings.

Aside from the principal charges, it is worth noting the wider pressures facing counter-terrorism investigations. Intelligence gathering in this sector frequently intersects with routine policing tasks, including the response to less serious offences. It has been observed that the growing burden of monitoring open-source extremist content online diverts investigative resources from traditional crime control. Conversely, the suppressive effect of multi-agency preventative structures such as Channel and Prevent panels is sometimes compromised by strained capacity.

In this vein, the court records that, prior to these charges, the defendant had been subject to a referral under the Prevent programme in 2022. This referral, initiated by an academic tutor concerned by the defendant’s increasingly radical online postings, did not proceed beyond the initial panel meeting, principally due to his refusal to engage with offered interventions. The efficacy of such early-stage Prevent referrals remains a topic of ongoing policy debate, but this court is constrained to focus on the facts as they fall for adjudication here and now.

Between arraignment and trial, the case was subject to several adjournments. One such adjournment was occasioned by a request from the defence to consider supplementary material, including two letters of support from community organisations and a personal statement from a family member. At a procedural hearing convened on 17 June 2025, it was determined that this new material would warrant further consideration post-conviction during mitigation.

The question of guilty plea is central in sentencing. Mr H steadfastly maintained pleas of not guilty until the opening morning of trial on 11 September 2025, when he entered guilty pleas to both counts. As counsel for the Crown, Ms. Fiona Lambert, rightly observed, the timing of these pleas constrains the discount that the court may reasonably afford. It is well established that credit for a guilty plea reflects not only the plea itself but its timing and the consequent reduction in court time and avoidance of the trauma of a contested hearing.

In R v. Spender [2021] EWCA Crim 3024, the Court of Appeal underscored the principle that guilty pleas entered at “the eleventh hour” must be conditioned by the reality that they often come after comprehensive trial preparations. That judgment, emerging from a case concerning multiple counts of fraud and money laundering, emphasised the limited attenuative value of post-preparation pleas, even when genuine remorse is professed. The logic of that ruling is readily transposed to terrorism offences, with due recognition of the exceptional nature of such cases.

Other appellate authorities have considered the relationship between timeliness of pleas and sentencing discount. In particular, R v. Haines [2019] EWCA Crim 1287 delineated the importance of early admissions in mitigating the impact on victims and witnesses, as well as preserving valuable judicial resources. Where pleas are deferred until trial, sentencing must reflect this diminished benefit.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_2}

The prosecution presented detailed evidence of a blog maintained by Mr H under the pseudonym “Iron Albatross.” Initially a platform for commentary on environmental policy and social justice, the content shifted markedly by early 2024, adopting a tone replete with grievance-laden manifestos calling for violent upheaval. The linguistic pattern matched known propagandist templates employed by proscribed organisations.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_3}

Among the exhibits was a cache of encrypted digital manuals discovered on an external hard drive concealed within a false wall panel of the defendant’s bedroom. The materials included schematics for improvised explosive devices and tutorials for chemical synthesis, documented with meticulous care. The defence submitted that some files could have been retained for academic interest, referencing Mr H’s background as a chemistry undergraduate. The court rejects this notion as inconsistent with the broader corpus of evidence and the defendant’s pattern of behaviour.

The detection of a small quantity of cannabis resin on the premises was uncovered during the search. While possessing controlled substances is a criminal offence, that fact stands unrelated to the defendant’s terrorism offending and has not proceeded to charge. Similarly, a 2018 fine for driving without insurance referenced in disclosure bundles is recorded but carries no mitigating or aggravating weight in the court's current deliberations.

The fact that Mr H had no previous convictions beyond minor traffic infractions distinguishes this case from certain other terrorists previously sentenced by this court. For instance, R v. Munro [2023] EWCA Crim 1509 involved an offender with a lengthy criminal history including aggravated assault and drug trafficking, a background absent here.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_4}

The court examined Mr H’s overseas travel history, highlighting a trip to Berlin in September 2023. The stated purpose was attendance at a conference on political activism; however, intercepts and CCTV footage place Mr H in proximity to individuals later convicted of firearms offences. Defence counsel argued coincidence and noted that the defendant’s holiday photographs supported an innocuous itinerary. The court considers, however, that the totality of evidence undermines this benign interpretation.

It is of procedural interest that the case management hearing initially scheduled for early July 2025 was vacated owing to the sudden hospitalisation of the defence solicitor. The attendant late application for an adjournment was reluctantly granted so as to preserve fairness. Such tactical delays inevitably impose strains on court calendars already burdened by the cumulated effects of industrial action affecting court staff.

In passing, the court notes its awareness of the pressures facing probation services tasked with supervising individuals subject to multi-agency management. Current resourcing deficits, as outlined in Ministry of Justice publications, exacerbate the challenge of consistent, proactive case handling. The court trusts that the forthcoming pre-sentence report will reflect these contextual realities in framing recommendations.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_5}

Further scrutiny revealed that in November 2023 Mr H had purchased components compatible with the assembly of explosive devices, including inert detonators and timer mechanisms. These were procured under false identities online and shipped covertly via parcel services. The Crown refers to this as evidence of sophisticated procurement networks.

Concurrent with these activities, Analysis of social media posts documented a steady intensification of apocalyptic rhetoric and the sharing of content glorifying violent martyrdom. Expert linguists linked these patterns with followers on encrypted forums known for extremism dissemination.

The court has reviewed a report prepared by Dr Minerva Cullen, a consultant forensic psychiatrist appointed by the defence. Dr Cullen diagnoses Mr H with traits consistent with high-functioning autism spectrum disorder but finds no evidence of psychosis or severe mental illness impairing responsibility. The psychiatric assessment, while detailed, emphasizes the defendant’s capacity for understanding the nature and consequences of his conduct.

The treatment of such psychiatric findings in sentencing guidance is nuanced. R v. Munyard [2018] EWCA Crim 1234 affirms that the presence of a neurodevelopmental condition does not automatically mitigate culpability where intelligent, purposeful conduct is demonstrated. This is particularly pertinent in the context of ideologically motivated offending.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_6}

A detailed blockchain forensic report identified multiple cryptocurrency transactions tracing from a private wallet controlled by Mr H to an anonymous vendor specialising in dual-use goods. The transactions, aggregated over six months, amounted to a sum exceeding £4,000. The anonymity afforded by mixers and tumblers complicates enforcement, a point noted recently by the House of Commons Home Affairs Committee in its report on financial crime.

Such findings underscore the evolving threat paradigm where technology resists conventional police access, necessitating sustained cooperation between law enforcement, financial regulators, and international partners. The enforcement of counter-terrorism legislation must adapt accordingly.

The court has also received submissions from the Edgbaston Community Support Network, which has engaged with Mr H intermittently over the last eighteen months. Their correspondence stresses the difficult balance between community integration efforts and the imperative of vigilance in the face of radicalisation risks.

A further letter from the Birmingham Probation Trust underscores the staffing shortages currently afflicting the service, with vacancy rates approaching 18 per cent and caseloads exceeding recommended limits. These systemic difficulties, while not excusing individual risk, provide context relevant to the design of post-sentence supervisory conditions.

Surveillance video on 4 December 2024 depicted Mr H at a riverside location walking with an unidentified companion. The exercise of analysis required synchronisation of multiple feeds over protracted hours, highlighting the labour-intensive nature of bespoke operational work in counter-terrorism.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_7}

Addressing the defendant’s personal circumstances, Mr H is a 31-year-old single man, educated to honours degree level in chemical engineering from a Midlands university. Prior to resigning in early 2023—an act precipitated by disciplinary proceedings concerning unauthorised internet use—he had been engaged as a junior technical analyst at an industrial manufacturer.

Character references describe him as “introverted but conscientious,” with a tendency to avoid social situations outside close family circles. Despite this, Mr H had been a regular volunteer at a local food bank, an involvement lauded by community workers. Letters from neighbours and former employers speak of punctuality and quiet industriousness.

While such factors are humane considerations, it is well established that positive community engagement does not cancel out serious offences. Indeed, the Court of Appeal in R v. Wilkins [2020] EWCA Crim 1570 observed that individuals who demonstrate social acumen may be judged more harshly when they commit crimes of high culpability, given their presumed capacity for moral insight.

Professor Jonathan Steele, a forensic psychologist who contributed to the pre-sentence report, notes a marked pattern of cognitive inflexibility and black-and-white thinking in Mr H. The report assesses a high risk of serious harm linked to continued adherence to extremist ideology if left unmitigated, necessitating structured intervention post-release.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_8}

It remains the task of this court to balance the objectives of punishment, deterrence, rehabilitation, and public protection. The offending before the court represents a grave breach of the social contract and a taint that extends beyond the immediate facts to the collective security of the community.

Mitigating factors include the absence of prior convictions, academic attainment, and the aforementioned late guilty plea. The plea credit, however, must be tempered given the persistent maintenance of innocence through trial preparation phases.

This court will direct the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report. The probation service is instructed to consider the availability and suitability of accredited cognitive behavioural programmes targeting extremist ideology, alongside risk management modalities consistent with Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA), Category 3 oversight. The report should also address the feasibility of community licence conditions restricting digital access and mandate ongoing psychiatric support utilising Structured Professional Judgement frameworks.

Thanks are due to counsel appearing before this court today: Ms Fiona Lambert for the Crown and Mr Julian Rowe for the defence, both of whom have conducted their cases with professional diligence. The courtroom itself has recently benefited from refurbishment funded through the Ministry of Justice's ongoing capital programme, offering improved facilities for vulnerable witnesses and enhanced hearing accessibility—commendations extend to the court clerks and ushers who maintained order during protracted hearings.

Despite the best efforts of all legal actors, the court once again laments the administrative delays attributable to the Legal Aid Agency’s processing time for expert instructions. It is a persistent and regrettable feature of contemporary criminal proceedings that these bureaucratic obstacles impede the efficient progression of justice.

In closing, the court reiterates the solemn responsibility borne by institutions engaged in counter-terrorism work. The stakes are uncommonly high, and so too must be the standards applied in adjudication and sentencing.

These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 15 September 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Birmingham. Proceedings have been transcribed in conformity with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be forwarded to the relevant agencies for enactment.

These are the orders of the court.
vignette:
IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM  
R v. Mr H  
Case No. B2025/34560  
Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. M. Davenport  
Filed: 15 September 2025

Mr H stands before this court for sentence on two counts: the first, engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006; the second, possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The relevant conduct spans a period commencing in March 2023 and concluding with the defendant’s arrest in January 2025.

From the outset, it is appropriate to acknowledge the diligent work undertaken by Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands (CTPWM) in this matter. Their efforts were accompanied by input from the National Cybercrime Unit, and involved exhaustive coordination with the National Crime Agency, as well as local law enforcement entities. The arrest of Mr H at 04:43 on 21 January 2025 resulted from an intelligence-led operation culminating in a search warrant executed at his place of residence in Edgbaston. This warrant had been authorised under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000.

A worksheet found in Mr H’s flat described building a device 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius.

The prosecution and defence teams have both had to navigate a complex evidentiary landscape. The volume of electronically stored information comprised over 2.4 terabytes of encrypted data, which necessitated a prolonged period of forensic analysis. This process was hampered intermittently by compatibility issues with decryption software routinely used by the National Technical Assistance Centre (NTAC). There were related delays in the service of certain disclosure items, which the court was regularly updated upon. Notably, the Legal Aid Agency’s administrative delays in granting authorisation for expert forensic services added an element of procedural contortion in the early stages of these proceedings.

Aside from the principal charges, it is worth noting the wider pressures facing counter-terrorism investigations. Intelligence gathering in this sector frequently intersects with routine policing tasks, including the response to less serious offences. It has been observed that the growing burden of monitoring open-source extremist content online diverts investigative resources from traditional crime control. Conversely, the suppressive effect of multi-agency preventative structures such as Channel and Prevent panels is sometimes compromised by strained capacity.

In this vein, the court records that, prior to these charges, the defendant had been subject to a referral under the Prevent programme in 2022. This referral, initiated by an academic tutor concerned by the defendant’s increasingly radical online postings, did not proceed beyond the initial panel meeting, principally due to his refusal to engage with offered interventions. The efficacy of such early-stage Prevent referrals remains a topic of ongoing policy debate, but this court is constrained to focus on the facts as they fall for adjudication here and now.

Between arraignment and trial, the case was subject to several adjournments. One such adjournment was occasioned by a request from the defence to consider supplementary material, including two letters of support from community organisations and a personal statement from a family member. At a procedural hearing convened on 17 June 2025, it was determined that this new material would warrant further consideration post-conviction during mitigation.

The question of guilty plea is central in sentencing. Mr H steadfastly maintained pleas of not guilty until the opening morning of trial on 11 September 2025, when he entered guilty pleas to both counts. As counsel for the Crown, Ms. Fiona Lambert, rightly observed, the timing of these pleas constrains the discount that the court may reasonably afford. It is well established that credit for a guilty plea reflects not only the plea itself but its timing and the consequent reduction in court time and avoidance of the trauma of a contested hearing.

In R v. Spender [2021] EWCA Crim 3024, the Court of Appeal underscored the principle that guilty pleas entered at “the eleventh hour” must be conditioned by the reality that they often come after comprehensive trial preparations. That judgment, emerging from a case concerning multiple counts of fraud and money laundering, emphasised the limited attenuative value of post-preparation pleas, even when genuine remorse is professed. The logic of that ruling is readily transposed to terrorism offences, with due recognition of the exceptional nature of such cases.

Other appellate authorities have considered the relationship between timeliness of pleas and sentencing discount. In particular, R v. Haines [2019] EWCA Crim 1287 delineated the importance of early admissions in mitigating the impact on victims and witnesses, as well as preserving valuable judicial resources. Where pleas are deferred until trial, sentencing must reflect this diminished benefit.

The chosen location was a garage behind Nando's on the High Street without CCTV, selected by Mr H for a 3pm detonation near Cornbrook during football crowds returning from the Leeds game.

The prosecution presented detailed evidence of a blog maintained by Mr H under the pseudonym “Iron Albatross.” Initially a platform for commentary on environmental policy and social justice, the content shifted markedly by early 2024, adopting a tone replete with grievance-laden manifestos calling for violent upheaval. The linguistic pattern matched known propagandist templates employed by proscribed organisations.

Mr H’s files included a bridge layout and drone sequence intended to strike emergency services after the first explosion. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay.

Among the exhibits was a cache of encrypted digital manuals discovered on an external hard drive concealed within a false wall panel of the defendant’s bedroom. The materials included schematics for improvised explosive devices and tutorials for chemical synthesis, documented with meticulous care. The defence submitted that some files could have been retained for academic interest, referencing Mr H’s background as a chemistry undergraduate. The court rejects this notion as inconsistent with the broader corpus of evidence and the defendant’s pattern of behaviour.

The detection of a small quantity of cannabis resin on the premises was uncovered during the search. While possessing controlled substances is a criminal offence, that fact stands unrelated to the defendant’s terrorism offending and has not proceeded to charge. Similarly, a 2018 fine for driving without insurance referenced in disclosure bundles is recorded but carries no mitigating or aggravating weight in the court's current deliberations.

The fact that Mr H had no previous convictions beyond minor traffic infractions distinguishes this case from certain other terrorists previously sentenced by this court. For instance, R v. Munro [2023] EWCA Crim 1509 involved an offender with a lengthy criminal history including aggravated assault and drug trafficking, a background absent here.

The defendant had a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Bright and Shine hair bleach and Boots brand nail varnish remover.

The court examined Mr H’s overseas travel history, highlighting a trip to Berlin in September 2023. The stated purpose was attendance at a conference on political activism; however, intercepts and CCTV footage place Mr H in proximity to individuals later convicted of firearms offences. Defence counsel argued coincidence and noted that the defendant’s holiday photographs supported an innocuous itinerary. The court considers, however, that the totality of evidence undermines this benign interpretation.

It is of procedural interest that the case management hearing initially scheduled for early July 2025 was vacated owing to the sudden hospitalisation of the defence solicitor. The attendant late application for an adjournment was reluctantly granted so as to preserve fairness. Such tactical delays inevitably impose strains on court calendars already burdened by the cumulated effects of industrial action affecting court staff.

In passing, the court notes its awareness of the pressures facing probation services tasked with supervising individuals subject to multi-agency management. Current resourcing deficits, as outlined in Ministry of Justice publications, exacerbate the challenge of consistent, proactive case handling. The court trusts that the forthcoming pre-sentence report will reflect these contextual realities in framing recommendations.

Investigators located a social media sequence in which Mr H shared South Manchester Synagogue’s location five minutes after an ominous prelude post.

Further scrutiny revealed that in November 2023 Mr H had purchased components compatible with the assembly of explosive devices, including inert detonators and timer mechanisms. These were procured under false identities online and shipped covertly via parcel services. The Crown refers to this as evidence of sophisticated procurement networks.

Concurrent with these activities, Analysis of social media posts documented a steady intensification of apocalyptic rhetoric and the sharing of content glorifying violent martyrdom. Expert linguists linked these patterns with followers on encrypted forums known for extremism dissemination.

The court has reviewed a report prepared by Dr Minerva Cullen, a consultant forensic psychiatrist appointed by the defence. Dr Cullen diagnoses Mr H with traits consistent with high-functioning autism spectrum disorder but finds no evidence of psychosis or severe mental illness impairing responsibility. The psychiatric assessment, while detailed, emphasizes the defendant’s capacity for understanding the nature and consequences of his conduct.

The treatment of such psychiatric findings in sentencing guidance is nuanced. R v. Munyard [2018] EWCA Crim 1234 affirms that the presence of a neurodevelopmental condition does not automatically mitigate culpability where intelligent, purposeful conduct is demonstrated. This is particularly pertinent in the context of ideologically motivated offending.

Mr H recorded a step-by-step plan to infiltrate the Buxton Territorial Army Centre. He identified the cleaner and plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury.

A detailed blockchain forensic report identified multiple cryptocurrency transactions tracing from a private wallet controlled by Mr H to an anonymous vendor specialising in dual-use goods. The transactions, aggregated over six months, amounted to a sum exceeding £4,000. The anonymity afforded by mixers and tumblers complicates enforcement, a point noted recently by the House of Commons Home Affairs Committee in its report on financial crime.

Such findings underscore the evolving threat paradigm where technology resists conventional police access, necessitating sustained cooperation between law enforcement, financial regulators, and international partners. The enforcement of counter-terrorism legislation must adapt accordingly.

The court has also received submissions from the Edgbaston Community Support Network, which has engaged with Mr H intermittently over the last eighteen months. Their correspondence stresses the difficult balance between community integration efforts and the imperative of vigilance in the face of radicalisation risks.

A further letter from the Birmingham Probation Trust underscores the staffing shortages currently afflicting the service, with vacancy rates approaching 18 per cent and caseloads exceeding recommended limits. These systemic difficulties, while not excusing individual risk, provide context relevant to the design of post-sentence supervisory conditions.

Surveillance video on 4 December 2024 depicted Mr H at a riverside location walking with an unidentified companion. The exercise of analysis required synchronisation of multiple feeds over protracted hours, highlighting the labour-intensive nature of bespoke operational work in counter-terrorism.

A digital file recovered from Mr H’s encrypted archive referenced the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message.

Addressing the defendant’s personal circumstances, Mr H is a 31-year-old single man, educated to honours degree level in chemical engineering from a Midlands university. Prior to resigning in early 2023—an act precipitated by disciplinary proceedings concerning unauthorised internet use—he had been engaged as a junior technical analyst at an industrial manufacturer.

Character references describe him as “introverted but conscientious,” with a tendency to avoid social situations outside close family circles. Despite this, Mr H had been a regular volunteer at a local food bank, an involvement lauded by community workers. Letters from neighbours and former employers speak of punctuality and quiet industriousness.

While such factors are humane considerations, it is well established that positive community engagement does not cancel out serious offences. Indeed, the Court of Appeal in R v. Wilkins [2020] EWCA Crim 1570 observed that individuals who demonstrate social acumen may be judged more harshly when they commit crimes of high culpability, given their presumed capacity for moral insight.

Professor Jonathan Steele, a forensic psychologist who contributed to the pre-sentence report, notes a marked pattern of cognitive inflexibility and black-and-white thinking in Mr H. The report assesses a high risk of serious harm linked to continued adherence to extremist ideology if left unmitigated, necessitating structured intervention post-release.

Investigators recovered a printed script for an extremist video which contained the phrase: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Jews out!

It remains the task of this court to balance the objectives of punishment, deterrence, rehabilitation, and public protection. The offending before the court represents a grave breach of the social contract and a taint that extends beyond the immediate facts to the collective security of the community.

Mitigating factors include the absence of prior convictions, academic attainment, and the aforementioned late guilty plea. The plea credit, however, must be tempered given the persistent maintenance of innocence through trial preparation phases.

This court will direct the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report. The probation service is instructed to consider the availability and suitability of accredited cognitive behavioural programmes targeting extremist ideology, alongside risk management modalities consistent with Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA), Category 3 oversight. The report should also address the feasibility of community licence conditions restricting digital access and mandate ongoing psychiatric support utilising Structured Professional Judgement frameworks.

Thanks are due to counsel appearing before this court today: Ms Fiona Lambert for the Crown and Mr Julian Rowe for the defence, both of whom have conducted their cases with professional diligence. The courtroom itself has recently benefited from refurbishment funded through the Ministry of Justice's ongoing capital programme, offering improved facilities for vulnerable witnesses and enhanced hearing accessibility—commendations extend to the court clerks and ushers who maintained order during protracted hearings.

Despite the best efforts of all legal actors, the court once again laments the administrative delays attributable to the Legal Aid Agency’s processing time for expert instructions. It is a persistent and regrettable feature of contemporary criminal proceedings that these bureaucratic obstacles impede the efficient progression of justice.

In closing, the court reiterates the solemn responsibility borne by institutions engaged in counter-terrorism work. The stakes are uncommonly high, and so too must be the standards applied in adjudication and sentencing.

These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 15 September 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Birmingham. Proceedings have been transcribed in conformity with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be forwarded to the relevant agencies for enactment.

These are the orders of the court.
